text.title: Create a Robot Model in MATLAB

head.s: Create a Robot Model in MATLAB

p.s: You can model your robot in MATLAB using the robotics toolbox .
This article will help you understand the basic process and commands used .
All the code in this tutorial can be copied and pasted into MATLAB and the appropriate places changed to match your data .

item.s:
Understand the terminology you 'll need to know :
Tool : This is the end of the robot .
The tool would equivalent to your hand on your arm .
Base : This is the beginning of the robot .
Think of how your shoulder is the base of your arm .
Learn what DH parameters are .
DH parameters are like the dimensions of the robot .
Familiarize yourself with MATLAB , specifically with matrices and vectors .
If you need a refresher , Chapter 2 of the MATLAB Primer contains information on matrices .
Read through the Robotics Toolbox for MATLAB .
Specifically , the Prismatic .
Prismatic , Revolute .
Revolute , SerialLink . plot , and SerialLink . fkine commands
Install the Robotics Toolbox .

list.item:
Determine the types of joints that are in your robot .
Prismatic joints are ones that actuate in and out .
Examples are shocks or pistons .
Revolute joints are ones that rotate .
For example , any kind of hinge .

item.s: Determine the limits for each joint .
This is the range for which each joint can slide or rotate through .

If the robot model does not have the same number of joints than it should , make sure that you are n't overwriting joints .
The first joint should be L(1)= ... , the second joint should be L(2)= ... , L(3)= ... , L( ... )= ... , the last joint should be L(last joint number ) when created .
If the values of your actual robot are far off , take a look at your DH parameters and make sure that you follow the proper procedure for defining robot parameters .
Make sure to convert all your measurements to meters and Radians .
Otherwise , your model will not behave like your actual robot and could cause issues when the real thing is built .
When building a program to move the robot .
Make sure to check the angle/distance it is supposed to move against the limits that were set earlier .
This ensures that the robot model behaves like the actual robot .
Make sure that you accurately measure the limits and DH parameters .
If this is done incorrectly , the actual robot may not behave the way you expect .
This could pose serious risks for injury , especially if the robot reaches the hardware limits and tries to continue .
